awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Rational Design and Engineering of Atomically Thin Interfaces for Electronic Devices
awd_abstract_narration:
The contact between metals and semiconductors is the foundation of modern day electronics. The high performance at relatively low energy cost in today's field effect transistors is achieved by decades long optimization of electrical contacts that has allowed the miniaturization of the device down to nanoscale dimensions. The search for new materials and devices to continue the development of advanced electronic has focused on 2-dimensional (2D) materials such as MoS2. 2D semiconductors that are naturally atomically thin can in principle provide higher performance. While the materials can provide advantages, their implementation is limited by the lack of a useful strategy to make electrical contact to the device. This grant looks to the fundamental nature of these contacts. The combined computational and experimental approach will seek new contact materials and structures to overcome this technological barrier. New contact strategies will be discovered and demonstrated leading to advances in the use of these new materials. Undergraduates will be engaged in the research activities drawing upon and developing underrepresented students into the work. 

The research seeks to develop a fundamental understanding of atomically thin interfaces formed between two dimensional (2D) materials with disparate properties. The lateral integration of 2D materials is a unique scientific problem that has not been systematically investigated. Novel atomic structures will be identified that are due to deformation induced by interfacial stress as well as the presence of new types of defects when two materials are 'stitched' together. The work examines the role of defects and the strain induced at the structural interface using multi-scale theoretical models, detailed structural characterization, and correlation of mechanics of the interface with electronic transport in field effect transistors. An iterative design approach will be developed that utilizes theoretical models to predict desired properties, experimentally realize hetero-interfaces of 2D materials, and characterize their atomic structure. The experimental work will provide input parameters for refinement of calculations while theoretical models will down select important combinations of 2D materials. This grant develops new theoretical and experimental methods for designing atomically thin interfaces with key 2D materials and their implementation as high performance electrical contacts for electronic systems. The materials selection knowledge for electrical contacts for 2D semiconductors will enable the next generation of high performance electronics that dissipate less heat leading to more energy efficient devices and do not require sophisticated thermal management strategies. The work incorporates undergraduates into the research activities drawing from underrepresented groups.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

por.por_cntn:
Award 1727531  

Rational Design and Engineering of Atomically Thin Interfaces for Electronic Devices 

The main goal of this project was to investigate and understand the effects of mechanical strains at the interface between conductive substrates and 2-dimensional transition metal dichalcogenides (2D-TMDs), notably MoS2. These interfaces form the electrical contacts that are essential to the performance and miniaturization of modern electronic devices such as field effect transistors, supercapacitors and batteries. The project utilized first principle simulations based on density functional theory (DFT) to examine the role of stresses in the deformation of specific bonds in 1T, 1T? and 1H MoS2. Additionally, the density of states and electrical properties as a function of the mechanical deformation were identified. Experimental verification was undertaken using micro-Raman spectroscopy to examine strains and conductive AFM to investigate electrical changes. 

Intellectual Merit 

The research has predicted the effect of strains induced by mechanical mismatches on the electronic properties of 2D-TMDs on conductive substrates. The DFT modeling indicates that MoS2 can exhibit electrical properties (metallic/semiconducting) that are dependent on the strain. The predictions confirm the potential to ?engineer? 2D-TMDs with specific electronic properties for energy storage applications. Experimentally the impact of mechanical mismatches on the deformation of individual bonds in thin MoS2 has been seen in micro-Raman studies of re-stacked exfoliated MoS2 on conductive substrates. The same system has been seen to store charge using AFM with cyclic voltammetry, and electrical impedance spectroscopy.   

Broader Impacts 

Technologically the research indicates an effective route to the successful integration of 2D-TMDs into large electronic devices using conductive substrates. The research has been undertaken by a graduate student (female, underrepresented minority) and an undergraduate student who have participated in both experimental and computational aspects of the work. The students have gained experimental skills and knowledge of advanced materials synthesis methods. The project helped to train and enhance the career prospects of these students in STEM. The research has been presented at several international conferences and is the basis for journal papers that are in preparation. The graduate student has been actively involved in the Rutgers Science Explorer (RSE) program also called the ?Science Bus?. This takes science experiments and demonstrations on the road to local schools and under-represented communities. 


Last Modified: 12/06/2021
Modified by: Richard L Lehman
